update.description:
The new `GZ3D.Ogre2Json` does on the browser what the `gzbridge`'s `OgreMaterialParser` and `ConfigLoader` do on the backend.

---

How it works:

1. It uses regex to convert an Ogre material script into JSON
1. Stores that JSON into `this.materialObj`
1. Collects specific material properties which are needed by `GZ3D.SdfParser`, following the same principle as `OgreMaterialParser`
1. Emits a `material` event with the materials (just like `gziface` does with the materials parsed using C++)

---

Other notes:

* The  example has been changed to make use of this, give it a try!
* Added dependency on lodash for more convenient handling of deep object properties
* Added the `npm run update-dev` command which concatenates files but doesn't lint or minify (convenient for developing)
* The tests should also give a good idea of how the new functions work
update.title: Client-side Ogre material parser

content.raw: Not on Fuel though... we need to decide how to handle `gazebo.materials` (and friends) there...
content.html: Not on Fuel though... we need to decide how to handle gazebo.materials (and friends) there...

content.raw: nice, bookshelf and double pendulum work now
content.html: nice, bookshelf and double pendulum work now

content.raw: Fixed a bunch more corner cases, now `gazebo.material` is parsed and results in 104 "materials".
content.html: Fixed a bunch more corner cases, now gazebo.material is parsed and results in 104 "materials".

content.raw: minor note that `alphaOpEx[3]`will not always exist. It only needs to be specified for certain alpha operations. So I think it’ll safer to add a check to see if  `alphaOpEx[3]` is `undefined`first
content.html: minor note that alphaOpEx[3]will not always exist. It only needs to be specified for certain alpha operations. So I think it’ll safer to add a check to see if alphaOpEx[3] is undefinedfirst

content.raw: Oh you're totally right, I didn't realize the name was changing from `alpha_op_ex` to `opacity`. I'll add it.
content.html: Oh you're totally right, I didn't realize the name was changing from alpha_op_ex to opacity. I'll add it.

content.raw: I think they get converted to `opacity` which are consumed by gzscene.js 's [setMaterial](#!/osrf/gzweb/src/5a7f0467f5abe2475a7f35a393a0f8651deb38b0/gz3d/src/gzscene.js#lines-2045) function.. I think..
content.html: I think they get converted to opacity which are consumed by gzscene.js 's setMaterial function.. I think..

content.raw: Yeah I thought we might not be able to... But instead of removing the whole block completely, I kept it there just in case... I couldn't think of a clever way to just remove them with regex
content.html: Yeah I thought we might not be able to... But instead of removing the whole block completely, I kept it there just in case... I couldn't think of a clever way to just remove them with regex

content.raw: Ah I forgot to mention. I didn't add it here because I didn't see any code on gz3d which uses it, but I can add it.
content.html: Ah I forgot to mention. I didn't add it here because I didn't see any code on gz3d which uses it, but I can add it.

content.raw: do you want to handle semi-transparent material specified using `alpha_op_ex` like in [OgreMaterialParser](#!/osrf/gzweb/src/5a7f0467f5abe2475a7f35a393a0f8651deb38b0/gzbridge/OgreMaterialParser.cc#lines-182)? There are quite a few of these operations in [gazebo.material](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/8bc98f4cf031fd36cae049fe2c90a072aeaf84a5/media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material#lines-500)
content.html: do you want to handle semi-transparent material specified using alpha_op_ex like in OgreMaterialParser? There are quite a few of these operations in gazebo.material

content.raw: those point to shader files but I’m not sure if we would be able to load them from the browser though.
content.html: those point to shader files but I’m not sure if we would be able to load them from the browser though.

update.description:
The new `GZ3D.Ogre2Json` does on the browser what the `gzbridge`'s `OgreMaterialParser` and `ConfigLoader` do on the backend.

---

How it works:

1. It uses regex to convert an Ogre material script into JSON
1. Stores that JSON into `this.materialObj`
1. Collects specific material properties which are needed by `GZ3D.SdfParser`, following the same principle as `OgreMaterialParser`
1. Emits a `material` event with the materials (just like `gziface` does with the materials parsed using C++)

* Added dependency on lodash for more convenient handling of deep object properties
* Added the `npm run update-dev` command which concatenates files but doesn't lint or minify (convenient for developing)
* The tests should also give a good idea of how the new functions work

content.raw:
Just saw that the following material has several details which this parser can't handle:

https://staging-api.ignitionfuel.org/1.0/openrobotics/models/Oak%20tree/1/files/materials/scripts/oak_tree.material

I'm looking into them.
